div.div: How are hierarchies used in task-based cognitive processes

Miles Sandlar
November 29th, 2012
Patrick T. Coyle
PSYC-4212

div.p: The question I wish to address is generally: how are hierarchies utilized in cognitive task-based processes? Additionally, this entails addressing specifically: what role hierachies serve in cognitive processes and additionally is the formtion of hierarchies in memory from tasks constructed bottom-up or in a top-down fashion. In answering what roles hierarchies serve in cognitive processes, a study of the literature reveals that organizing tasks into mental hierarchierces provides structure for enabling meaningful relationships between various sets of tasks and sub-tasks . As such, if your ultimate goal is to bake a cake, there are several tasks and numerous nested sub-tasks that must be achieved in order to achieve to the ultimate goal of getting the baked cake (first must make the batter, then put the batter in a tray, then in the oven, and so on in a sequential ordering of tasks). While, this top-down decomposition of cognitive tasks seems omnipresent when retrospecitvly anlyzing tasks, when addressing each specific task or sub-task, the hierarchy can be seen as being utilzed bottom-up. As such, there are multiple ways to prepare the battter, multiple trays to put the batter in, and numerous ways to make the batter rise. As such, in the analysis of congitive tasks, the top-down/bottom-up distinction is not so clear cut. Hence, there is a interconnected bi-directional relation between the tasks of a hierarchy's end goals and the tasks themselves. Addressing this discordance between hierarchies instantiated top-down versus bottom-up in relation to memory is severly lacking in the literature. The view I wish to develop through this survey of the literature is that task hierarchies need a more complex abstraction of memory in order fully understood.

div.div: Burns, C. & Vicente, K. (2001). Model-Based Approaches for Analyzing Cognitive Work: A Comparison of Abstraciton Hierarchy, Multilevel Flow Modeling, and Decision Ladder Modeling. Journal of Cognitive Ergonomics, 5, 357-366.
div.p: This article surveys existing literatere to understand model-based approaches to cognitive task processes. It's authors do so by considered three distinictive models utilzied in analyzing cognitive tasks: the Abstraction Hierarchy (AH), Multilevel Flow Modeling (MF), and Decision Ladder Modeling (DL). Work domain structure models (WDS) and Work Domain Goal models (WDG) are distinguished as being two types of approaches which the three models at hand can be classified in the contenxt of. WDS models describe the structure of the system being controlled. WDS models exist independent of worker, automation, task, or interface. WDS purely describes abstraction and not iimplementation. Contrarilty, WDG models describes the goals of components of a system such as the desired states. Additionally one more abstraction must be provided to understand the three models at hand. Action-means-end (AME) is to be in contrast to stuctural-means-end (SME). Where AME describes actions which conduce means to an end goal in a WDG framwork, SME simply describes the structural relation between the means and the end goal.

div.div: Dixon, p. (1987). the structure of mental plans for following directions. journal of experimental psychology, 13, 18-26.
div.p: This study illustrates how the phrasing of written directions creates a cognitive hierarchial representation of tasks. In this study, subjects were provided sentences in which information needed to construct a cognitive task was embeded in the sentence. One such example of a sentence used was: "press button A to turn light Y on". In this example, in order to understand and cognitivly process the direction "turn light Y on", the dependency embeded in the sentence of "press button A" needed to be first be processed. Thus, a hierarchy of tasks in each trial was induced in either a top-down or bottom-up fashion depending on the placement of the depenednet clause. This study found that when the goal proceeded the dependent action, such as: "light Y should be on after pressing button A", execution time was both slower and less accurate than when the dependent action proceeded the goal outright. This gives support that forming mental hierarchiecial models of tasks based on directions is more efficient when approached from a bottom-up or constructive persepective.

These results positivly adress my research question by showing that when actions are translated into written language that hierarchies can be seen in by way of the nature of task-dependence. Additionally, this study adds that bottom-up processing seems more effective then top-down processing of task hierarchies in application to simple sets of tasks. I would like to positivly note that the scope of the directions encoded to tasks in this study do not provide grounding that bottom-up cognitive processing of task hierechiaies is more efficient than bottom-down methodologies. The directions used to describe tasks in the current study were simple and not-representative of any sort of complex higher-order tasks in which hierarchies are seemingly more useful. as such, the current study could be seen as an analysis of sequential information processing just as easily as it could be seen as an analysis of hierarchial information processing.

div.div: Christie, J. &, A comparison of simple hierarchy and grid metaphors for option layouts on small-size screens
div.p: This study questions the need for hierarchies in option selection tasks all together. While for some complex tasks hierarchies are a necessary construct as they the result of top-down analysis of each sub-task this is not always the case. For simple option selection categorization within hierarchial structures provides a way to organize tasks. While performance in such examples actually suffered, subjects maintained a preference for hierarhcially ordeered item selection over simple single isolated task item selection. This addreses the oher studies by showing the cognitive need and function of hierarchies in tasks: organization. Hierarchies help provide meaningful relations between items such that each item (and resulting selection-taski in the context of this study) can be understood in context to the other items. Again, as with the last study, this study only seeked to analyze relativly simple cognitive tasks and thus we must question: would these results generalize to more complex cognitive tasks? It may be the case that at a certain level of cognitive processing that hierarchial structure in understanding the depdnence of tasks must be imposed.

div.div: Objection recognition and segmentation by a fragment-based hierarchy
div.p: This article suggests an that in the task of objection recognition, we use a hierarchial structure to identify properties or parts as conforming to a whole. For example, when we recognize a dog "object", the reason we are justified in saying that it is a dog and not some other object is that numerous components which can be organized hierarchial to conform to the properties of a dog. As such a dog, inherits properties from other animals, as such it has a face, and associated with its face it has ears of a certain type, a nose of a certain type, and so on and so forth. This article additionally suggests that the same properties we use to construct a hierarchial model of particular objects is used subsequently in a top-down fashion to delineate between objects and further used to classify objects. Thus, in the view of the author of this article, the cognitive process or task of categorization is nothing more than comparing existing known hierarchies of objects to see which hierarchial representation could most likely fit the object in question.
